## Question

![](../img/qr_vevox.svg)

## Data repositories

-   Deposit data/files to resources that are:

    -   **Specific**: best metadata annotations

    -   **Widely used**: continuity and findability

-   Find a repository on [re3data.org](https://www.re3data.org/) or [fairsharing.org](https://fairsharing.org/)

-   If there's no specific repo, there are general ones, e.g.:

    -   [figshare](http://figshare.com/)

    -   [Open Science Framework](http://osf.io/)

    -   [Zenodo](http://zenodo.org/)

## General repositories - file types

-   Documents (e.g. pdf/MS Word)

-   Images

-   Presentations

-   Spreadsheets

-   File collections, e.g. tarballs

## Zenodo

-   Initiative of CERN (you know, from the Large Hadron Collider), OpenAire and EU

-   Aims for long-term storage

-   Assign DOI and make digital objects citable

-   Maximum file size: 50 Gb

-   Versioning

-   GitHub integration

![](https://about.zenodo.org/static/img/logos/zenodo-gradient-round.svg){.absolute top="380" right="50" width="400"}

## Zenodo - GitHub integration

-   Create a record, version and DOI upon release

-   Uses [`CITATION.cff`](https://citation-file-format.github.io/) for metadata annotation

-   And/or `.zenodo.json` using the [deposit metadata schema](https://developers.zenodo.org/#deposit-metadata), with e.g.:

    -   Creators

    -   License

    -   Title

    -   Keywords

    -   ..

![](../img/zenodo_releases.png){.absolute top="340" right="50" width="500"}
